snippet: Cornelius Gurlitt, the reclusive son of a Nazi-era art dealer, told a German newsmagazine that the confiscation of some 1,280 masterworks from his home was more devastating than his sister’s death.
abstract: Cornelius Gurlitt of Munich, reclusive son of Nazi-era art dealer, gives his first interview since his collection of some 1,280 masterworks, estimated to be worth $1 billion, was confiscated by German authorities in 2012; says that his sudden fame as keeper of largest trove of masterworks uncovered since World War II has left him bewildered; German authorities are still trying to determine rightful ownership of the collection and whether Gurlitt broke any laws.

byline.original: By ANDREW HIGGINS and KATRIN BENNHOLD
byline.contributor: Melissa Eddy contributed reporting from Berlin, Chris Cottrell from Munich and Patricia Cohen from New York.

lead_paragraph: Cornelius Gurlitt, the reclusive son of a Nazi-era art dealer, told a German newsmagazine that the confiscation of some 1,280 masterworks from his home was more devastating than his sister’s death.

headline.main: For Son of a Nazi-Era Dealer, a Private Life Amid a Tainted Trove of Art
